definition: In genetics, **"2n"** denotes the <u>diploid number of chromosomes</u> in a cell. The symbol n represents a single set of chromosomes (the haploid number), so 2n means <u>two sets</u>. For example, if n = 23 for humans, <u>2n = 46</u>. A 2n cell has paired chromosomes (one set from each parent).
tips: Think of n as the count of unique chromosomes. In humans, <u>n = 23</u> (unique chromosomes 1 through 22, plus X or Y). Therefore 2n (two of each) = **46**.
When solving problems, if you see "2n = X," you can immediately find <u>n = X/2</u>. Likewise, if n is given, 2n is just double it.

Different species have different n values. The concept of 2n applies to all diploid organisms: for example, a pea plant has <u>2n = 14</u> (so <u>n = 7</u>). Always clarify which organism's context you're in.
exam_appearance: An exam may present something like "Organism Y has 2n = 18" and then ask how many chromosomes are in a gamete or in a somatic cell after mitosis, etc. Recognize <u>2n as the full set and n as half</u>.
If a cell is described as 2n, it's a <u>diploid cell</u>. For instance, a question might ask: "Is a liver cell 2n or n?" Since a liver cell is a body (somatic) cell, it's 2n (diploid).
